title: Brittney Griner’s Nightmare Continues
subtitle: The American athlete’s trial is set to begin, as a Russian court again extends her detention

metadata.excerpt: A resolution to Brittney Griner’s detainment took one step forward and another step back at a closed-door hearing in a Khimki city court near Moscow on June 27. The trial for the WNBA star, who has been in custody since Feb. 17—when Russian authorities allege she smuggled cannabis oil into the country—finally got a start date of July 1. But Griner, 31, was also ordered to remain in custody for an additional six months, pending a verdict, according to her attorney Alexander Boikov. If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in prison.

components.text: TTTTTTTTTTTTThe American athlete’s trial is set to begin, as a Russian court again extends her detention

caption.text: Brittney Griner in a Khimki court on June 27.

components.text: Brittney Griner in a Khimki court on June 27.

A resolution to Brittney Griner’s detainment took one step forward and another step back at a closed-door hearing in a Khimki city court near Moscow on June 27. The trial for the WNBA star, who has been in custody since Feb. 17—when Russian authorities allege she smuggled cannabis oil into the country—finally got a start date of July 1. But Griner, 31, was also ordered to remain in custody for an additional six months, pending a verdict, according to her attorney Alexander Boikov. If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in prison.

Three days before Griner’s preliminary hearing, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a bipartisan resolution calling for her immediate release. “Not a day goes by that we aren’t thinking of Brittney and working to get her home,” said Rep. Greg Stanton of Arizona.

Griner’s wife, Cherelle—who told the Associated Press she has “zero trust in our government” after a phone call with Griner scheduled for June 18 went unconnected due to a “logistical error” by the State Department—nevertheless praised Congress’s efforts. Said Cherelle in a statement: “We need to be doing all we can to keep Brittney’s case on the forefront.”
